learning_outcomes.description: Discuss how to partner, collaborate, and advocate for communities in speech pathology practice
Identify speech pathology needs of a community
Enhance the capability and capacity of community members to support individuals with communication and swallowing needs

Explain how speech pathologists would provide service level responses for communities that are informed by the goals and needs of the community, planned and delivered using best available evidence, and guided by local context
Implement community health promotion and prevention activities to address social determinants of health inequity in speech pathology

Explore how social determinants and ways of knowing and being can support the development of culturally responsive services when working in collaboration with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, Elders and cultural leaders
Explain how to engage in culturally responsive care when working in collaboration with culturally and linguistically diverse communities

assessments.assessment_title: Group Debate: The value of investment in community-focussed activities
assessments.task_description:
This task will be assessed during tutorial time. It aims to develop students' skills in advocating for community-focussed activities and health promotion and prevention initiatives within speech pathology practice. It aligns with the need for speech pathologists to effectively communicate and influence decision-makers in their workplace.

Part A - Prior to the tutorial in Week 4, groups will be assigned a topic and stance ('for' or 'against') related to community-focused or health promotion and prevention activities. In their group, students will participate in a structured debate with the opposing group assigned to the same topic.

Part B - Following the debate, students will complete a UQ peer evaluation tool, Buddycheck, to demonstrate how each student has contributed to the debate.


The task description and marking criteria will be made available on Blackboard.

All presentations will be recorded for marking and moderation purposes only. These recordings will not be released to Blackboard and will be only used by the course staff.


Extensions

Extensions can be requested for this assessment item. Please apply for an extension request via my.UQ > my.UQ Dashboard > my. Requests  and provide evidence of circumstance, as soon as it becomes evident that an extension is needed, but no later than the assessment item submission date. Further information regarding what constitutes an acceptable reason for an extension is listed on the my.UQ website: Applying for an extension - my.UQ - University of Queensland


*This assessment item is a group assessment. If a student is unable to attend a tutorial due to medical or other valid reasons, the group is still expected to complete

the task collectively during the tutorial and receive a group mark. The student who was absent should anticipate a similar individual task and is required to

submit an extension request via My Requests before the tutorial, and also email the course coordinator - Dr Katelyn Melvin (k.melvin@uq.edu.au) in advance to

arrange for the assessment to be completed individually at a later date.


Use of AI

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

This assessment has been designed to be completed by students after they engage with Module 4 of the Understanding Cultural Safety modules. Students will be provided with a cultural safety continuum reflective tool and template to develop a professional action plan. They will identify three specific actions they will take to advance their culturally safe practice, and link these actions to the stages of the cultural safety continuum (i.e., unlearning, learning, applying, reflecting, embedding).

assessments.assessment_title: Needs Analysis and Elevator Pitch Assignment
assessments.task_description:
This assignment challenges you to critically analyse health and communication/ swallowing challenges within the Australian context, identify gaps in current approaches, and propose collaborative solutions.

This task has two parts, which are submitted together.

Part A - Students will be asked to respond to a contemporary issue and advocate for individuals in a community. Students will first complete a written task, which will include a needs analysis for their assigned community (20% weighting). They will discuss the role of the speech pathologist in supporting the needs of that community with reference to recent literature.

Part B - Students will then submit a recorded elevator pitch (oral presentation) focusing on a solution to the contemporary issue, outlining a community proposal, and justifying why their proposed solution should be funded and implemented (20% weighting).


The task description and marking criteria will be made available on Blackboard.

assessments.task_description:
In this final assessment, students will complete a written exam featuring a case-based community scenario. Drawing on course content, students will apply principles of community development and engagement to outline their approach to working with the community in the scenario. The exam will also require students to reflect on the evolving role of the speech pathologist, integrating key learnings from SPCH3211. This assessment is designed to evaluate students' ability to synthesise theory and practice in context.


This exam will be delivered in Inspera Assessment and will be completed on your personal laptop on campus.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
